Lines.Text:
Here's a question from Sandeep who 
lives in Peoria, Illinois. He asks,

"If non-dual brahman is the ultimate 
reality, then why did the ancient rishis say

that Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva are the gods 
of creation, sustenance, and dissolution?"

Questions like this one often arise when we 
look at conventional Hindu teachings from the

lofty standpoint of non-duality, advaita. 
The scriptures of advaita Vedanta accept

only one, undifferentiated underlying reality 
called brahman. But most other scriptures accept

the existence of many gods. These two positions 
are contradictory and seem irreconcilable.

But, this apparent conflict can be resolved 
with the help of an important principle

that applies to all Hindu scriptures, yet it's 
seldom discussed except in scholarly commentaries.

That principle is called adhikari bheda.
Bheda means difference,

and the expression adhikari bheda 
refers to differences among people

who have a wide range of educational backgrounds, 
who come from various social and economic groups,

who have distinct personalities, 
different emotional temperaments,

and so on. The level of diversity among people is 
astounding. We all differ in the foods we like,

the kinds of entertainment we enjoy, the clothes 
we wear, and in thousands of other ways. So, it's

no surprise that we also differ from one another 
in our religious and spiritual inclinations.

The principle of adhikari bheda acknowledges 
these differences and wholeheartedly embraces them

by enabling the Hindu tradition to provide 
different religious and spiritual teachings

to different people, according to their 
individual preferences, needs and capabilities.

This principle is commonly found elsewhere, like 
in our schools. Students first learn basic math.

Later, they learn algebra, geometry, 
and trigonometry. And later yet, they

might learn calculus. Each of these subjects are 
taught according to a student's age and ability.

Not surprisingly, some students advance 
more rapidly than their peers, while

others opt out of advanced classes. 
It's different for each individual.

All this holds true for the study of 
religious and spiritual teachings as well.

First we learn the basics, about God, 
prayer, and the importance of dharma.

Then, we gradually proceed to more complex 
topics, to the extent we're inclined to do so.

And, just like students have different books for 
algebra, geometry, and so on, in the same way,

we have different scriptures that present a wide 
range of religious and spiritual subjects.

Consider this. Young children would find a 
calculus textbook to be incomprehensible.

In the same way, those just beginning their 
spiritual journeys would probably find the

loftiest teachings of Advaita Vedanta to be 
beyond their reach. Before studying calculus,

students have to be adequately prepared by 
studying algebra and the rest. It's the same

for spiritual seekers. Before they can grasp 
the highest teachings of non-duality, they too,

have to be adequately prepared. Traditional 
Vedanta texts list the necessary prerequisites.

Those prerequisites include the cultivation 
of qualities like discernment, dispassion

toward worldly pleasures, equanimity, 
and self-control, in addition to prayer,

meditation, and the study of introductory texts 
under the guidance of a qualified teacher.

A problem I've noticed from time to time is 
that some advanced spiritual students claim

that Advaita Vedanta is better than other 
teachings because it reveals the highest reality,

non-dual brahman. But their claims 
really aren't justified at all.

A book on advanced calculus isn't better than 
an introductory algebra text. These books have

different subject matters and are intended for 
students of different levels. In the same way,

our scriptures have different subject matters, 
intended for different types of students.

For example, consider the Upanishads, the 
scriptures on which Advaita Vedanta is based.

They're primarily focused on teaching non-duality 
for those who are adequately prepared for

that profound subject matter. The Ramayana and 
Mahabharata mostly teach dharma, righteousness,

for those who need guidance in coping 
with the complexities of day to day life.

The eighteen Puranas recount the lives of ancient 
saints and tell stories about gods like Brahma,

Vishnu, Shiva, for those who want to 
cultivate their prayer and devotion. It's true

that each of these scriptures 
include a range of subjects,

including topics found in other scriptures, 
so there's a lot of overlap. But in general,

each scripture has a primary subject matter 
that's meant for a particular group of people.

For these reasons, no single scripture or 
teaching tradition can really be considered best.

It's more accurate to say that certain 
scriptures and teachings are well-suited

for someone's unique preferences, needs, and 
capabilities, while other scriptures are not.

The principle of adhikari bheda also explains why 
there are so many gods in the Hindu tradition.

The earliest Hindu scripture, Rig Veda, 
clearly says, "God is one, which the

wise call by many names." How many names? The 
Puranic scriptures refer to 330 million gods,

all of them different names and forms for the 
one god of the cosmos. That huge number is

interesting because it's more than the population 
of our planet in ancient times. That means, each

person could worship his or her own individual 
form of god, worshipped by no one else.

This observation shows how the Hindu approach 
to devotional life recognizes the importance of

personal preferences and religious inclinations. 
The Hindu tradition allows and encourages

followers to choose a particular form of god 
as their main focus for prayer and worship.

This attitude is refreshingly 
different from most other religions

that prescribe one and only one 
form of god for prayer and worship.

In my classes for children, I jokingly call this a 
"one size fits all" approach to religion. One size

of clothing certainly doesn't fit our many 
different shapes and sizes. So how can one

form of god be suitable for us all, given our 
wide range of preferences and inclinations?

Another question that's related to the principle 
of adhikari bheda comes from Ramya in India.

She asks, "What's your view on the philosophy of 
Dvaita, duality, because it seems contradictory

to the philosophy of Advaita." In 
fact, the teachings of Vedanta include

several different schools of thought that were 
established by greatly-revered scholars long ago.

In the eighth century, Shankara developed the 
teachings of Advaita or non-dualistic Vedanta.

Three centuries later, Ramanuja developed 
the teachings of Vishishta Advaita,

or qualified non-dualism. Later yet, Madhva 
developed the teachings of Dvaita, dualism.

We can t get into the details of these three 
schools of thought, so here's a brief but

highly oversimplified account. Dvaita, dualism, 
teaches that God is separate and distinct from

all individual souls, from the consciousness or 
awareness that's the essential nature of us all.

Vishishta Advaita, qualified non-dualism, teaches 
that each individual soul is a small part of God

and shares God's divine qualities. And Advaita 
boldly declares that there's only God, nothing

else. All that exists is a form 
or manifestation of the divine.

All three teachings seek to explain the very 
same reality, but they adopt three different

perspectives for their explanations. 
To understand the dualistic perspective

of Dvaita, suppose you gaze at the ocean and see 
many individual waves. You could observe how each

wave is born from the ocean, sustained by the 
ocean, and eventually returns to the ocean.

This metaphor nicely represents Dvaita's teachings 
about the relationship between individual souls

and God, who is the source, sustainer, and 
ultimate destination for all that exists.

To understand Vishistha Advaita's view, suppose 
you consider the fact that each wave is actually

a small part of the ocean. The ocean is made 
of countless waves that share its qualities.

This metaphor represents the teachings of 
Vishistha Advaita. Each individual soul

is a small part of God, a spark of 
divinity as they say. And God is the unity

because of which the diversity of souls exists. 
Finally, to understand Advaita's view, suppose

you appreciate the fact that, ultimately, there's 
only water; there are no waves or ocean at all.

This metaphor represents Advaita's sole 
acceptance of one, non-dual brahman.

Regarding the ocean, you can't say that one 
perspective is right and the others are wrong.

Each is correct from its own standpoint. But 
the three perspectives do differ in complexity

and subtlety. One ocean with many waves is 
a simple concept. It's a bit more complex

to say that each wave is part of the ocean. 
And to say, there are no waves or ocean,

there's only water, is quite subtle since it 
requires a radical shift of perspective.

All this holds true for the three Vedantic 
schools of thought as well. You can't say one

is right and the others are wrong because each 
is correct from its own standpoint. But they do

differ in complexity and subtlety, and that's 
where the principle of adhikari bheda comes in.

For those just setting out on a spiritual 
path, Dvaita is a good starting point,

not just because it's the simplest of the 
three, but because it most strongly supports

the practice of prayer, and prayer 
is essential for spiritual growth.

The teachings of Dvaita are sufficient for a 
lifelong practice of prayer and worship, but for

those who want to understand their relationship 
with God more deeply, it might be helpful to

explore the teachings of Vishishta Advaita 
or Advaita. It all depends on the individual.

Based on the principle of adhikari bheda, any of 
these three three teachings can be followed.

The many different scriptures, gods and 
teachings found in the Hindu tradition are all

examples of adhikari bheda. This principle often 
goes unrecognized, but it's crucial because it

ensures that individual religious and 
spiritual needs are never ignored.

This is the eighth video in a series that 
answers questions submitted by viewers. If

you have a question that would serve as 
a good topic for a video like this one,

please email me at this address, and be 
sure to indicate "video question" as the

subject of the email. I'll try to address 
your question in a future video.

Title: If Reality is NON-DUAL, Why are there so many GODS in Hinduism?
Description:
Hindu scriptures offer different teachings to meet the individual needs of different people - according to the crucial principle of adhikari-bheda (individualism). Q&A with Swamiji #8. 

The teachings of the rishis, the sages of ancient India, are found in the Vedas. The Vedas are a compilation of their teachings, teaching meant for different groups of people. Thus the Vedas include the karma kanda, the section that teaches prayer and rituals for those who want contentment in this life and heaven (swarga) in the next live, and it also includes the jnana kanda, the section on pure spiritual teachings, for those who recognize the limitations of worldly life (samsara) and seek moksha, liberation or enlightenment, instead.

Swami Tadatmananda is a traditionally-trained teacher of Advaita Vedanta, meditation, and Sanskrit. For more information, please see: https://www.arshabodha.org/
